chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected syphilis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Take a history and ask about:

  • Symptoms of syphilis.
  • Risk factors, including a full sexual history.
  • Past medical history including previously diagnosed sexually transmitted infections and treatment.

Examine the person

  • In early disease, examination may include: 
    • Genital examination — looking for chancre.
    • Skin examination including mouth, scalp, palms and soles — looking for skin lesions such as maculopapular rash, mucous patches or condylomata lata. 
    • Neurological examination — looking for neurological signs (including meningitis, stroke and cranial nerve lesions).
    • Eye examination — looking for signs of ocular disease.
  • In symptomatic late disease, examination may include:
    • Skin examination — looking for signs such as gumma. 
    • Cardiovascular system — looking for signs of cardiovascular disease including aortic regurgitation.
    • Nervous system — looking for signs of tabes dorsalis or general paresis. 
    • Eye examination — looking for signs of ocular disease. 

Refer for investigations

  • Refer to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) specialist for laboratory investigations (such as dark-field microscopy and serology) and a full sexual health screen (including HIV testing).
    • For more information on specialist investigations for the diagnosis of syphilis see the Section on Laboratory diagnosis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment of a person with suspected syphilis are based on clinical guidelines Sexually transmitted diseases treatment guidelines [CDC, 2015b], UK national guidelines on the management of syphilis 2015 [Kingston, 2016] and Syphilis. Management summary [New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017], UK national guidelines on the management of syphilis [BASHH, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Nyatsanza, 2016; Watts, 2016; O’Byrne, 2019; New York City Department of Health and New York City STD Prevention Training Center, 2019]. 

Ocular syphilis

  • The number of cases of ocular syphilis has increased since 2014, especially in men who have sex with men [ECDC, 2019]. 
    • A 2-year national surveillance study of intraocular inflammation secondary to ocular syphilis (the British Ocular syphilis study [BOSS]) identified 41 new cases of ocular syphilis with an estimated annual incidence of 0.3 cases per million UK adult population. Panuveitis was the most commonly identified ophthalmological diagnosis [Mathew, 2014]. 
  • Ocular syphilis may present with blurred vision, visual loss, eye pain or redness — additional systemic features may not be present [New York City Department of Health and New York City STD Prevention Training Center, 2019].

Referral to GUM for investigations

  • Referral to GUM is widely recommended to ensure that appropriate diagnostic testing, full sexual health screening (including HIV testing) and disease staging are carried out [Lazaro, 2013; Kingston, 2016; New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017].
    • Diagnosis is made through a combination of clinical assessment and laboratory tests — interpretation of tests is difficult and requires specialist input [New Zealand Sexual Health Society, 2017]. 
      • A variety of tests with differing sensitivities and specificities depending on the stage of infection are available — some serological tests used for diagnosis of syphilis also detect antibodies raised in response to non-venereal treponema [PHE, 2016]. 
      • False positives and false negative results may occur.
      • Repeat testing is required with timing and type of test dependant on the specific clinical situation.
    • Staging of syphilis is needed to determine appropriate treatment, expected treatment response, follow-up, and look back period for contact tracing [O’Byrne, 2019]. 
    • Full sexual health screen is indicated as syphilis shares common risk factors with other sexually transmitted infections.
